div.p: 1. V. Friday

I wrote to Governor Lincoln, notifying him of the appointment of the Committee of Overseers and requesting him to fix a time some day next week, for the meeting of the Committee at the house of Coll. B. T. Pickman at Boston—and I enclosed to him the Statement yesterday made by President Quincy— Charles took my Letter with him to Boston to send it by this day’s Mail— I visited my garden, but was called from it by Isaac Hull Adams, who being on his way to West-Point, received at Boston an answer to his application for an extension of his furlough, with a consent to its extension until the 15th. of this Month. I received also a Letter from my wife, written last Monday: in the body of the Letter uncertain whether she should leave Washington that day or not; and on the cover of the Letter, under the superscription written “departure postponed.” I wrote a line to Charles, informing him of this fact— The remainder of the day was employed in journalizing the two last days, and in continuing to assort my private papers—a task which will take much more time than I had anticipated; but which to do methodically I must reserve, for afternoon’s work— The weather was this day cool, and pleasant, so that I was able to write as much after as before dinner— In the Evening I visited Mr Whitney and spent an hour with him, and his Son Augustus— I felt all the morning some anxiety for Durant the Aeronaut: but it was relieved by learning before Night that he had been saved— After being in the air about an hour and a half, he came down at Sea, about 5 Miles East of Cape Ann, and was taken up, by a boat from the Schooner Miner, Captain Spaulding from Thomastown Maine, and came into Boston harbour, about nine O’Clock this morning— His preservation was almost miraculous.
2. V. Saturday

Occupations accumulate upon me— I visited this morning my Garden and Nursery— My Seedlings are so multiplied that they furnish matter for continual observations many of which are curious; but they are barren—they pass out of the memory and lead to no improvement— Observation is useless unless accompanied by meditation; and followed by the action of experiment— Then too, there must be the memory of the experiment—the observation of its results, and sagacious enquiry into the causes of its success or failure— I have planted many whole Apples, and it frequently happens, that two, three or four seedlings come up in a cluster from one apple— I have never settled, when they should be separated— This morning I took away two out of three Apple seedlings, which came up together—left the tallest in the place where it came up, and set out the two others in a line with it, about a foot distant from it and from each other— The question is whether this is a safe time for transplanting—and I make it as an experiment— I find in several places seedling Strawberries, from seeds which I sowed last year in July, but in most cases they are smothered with weeds— All my vines which I had thought killed last November by the frost are alive, and creeping along for support— Several new ones are up from seeds sown last year— It is with trees as with animals much easier to breed than to bring them up— Many of my seedlings of the present year are as usual perishing
under the heat of the Sun— I have filled two of the Earthen Pots which I left last year, with seeds sown in them, none of which have come up, with new Earth; and put in them Strawberry seeds—Lime berries, and Plum stones— I began a draught of a Report to the Overseers of Harvard University, upon the recent disorders among the Students— Afternoon visit from Mr F. C. Gray and Mr W. B. Lawrence— While they were here, about five O’Clock my wife arrived safely from Washington, with Walter Hellen, my Son John’s daughter Mary Louisa, and Mrs Wilson— They found the Carriage and horses, and Wilson waiting for them at Dedham, and came home in the Carriage— They left Washington Wednesday afternoon.
3. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Peter Whitney, this morning from John 14.6. “I am the way, and the truth, and the life.”—a Communion discourse, and he administered the communion after the ordinary service— There were no female singers in the choir— The afternoon Sermon was from Ecclesiastes 5.1. [“]Keep thy foot when thou goest to the house of God, and be more ready to hear than to give the sacrifice of fools: for they consider not that they do evil.” Two female singers in the Choir—Louisa C Smith and I. H. Adams were here after Meeting this afternoon— I read the 10th. Sermon of the 5th. Volume of Saurin, which was for a fast day, on the 13th. of November 1720. This Sermon was preached at a time of great public distress. He speaks of a mortality among the cattle, and says it had continued many years—of suspended credit—of failing commerce—of multitudes of families ruined, and many others touching upon ruin— These complaints seem to be of all times in commercial Countries— Among the instruments of divine indignation he enumerates wind—the horn distemper—the plague in France, and stock-jobbing— There is something ludicrous in this catalogue of Scourges— The wind for example— Tempestuous times— He says there had been within the preceding ten years so many storms that it seemed as if Nature was falling into her primitive Chaos— The horn-distemper— He says they had suffered so long from this, that they had grown accustomed to it, and scarcely regarded it as a misfortune— The Plague in France— It had not reached Holland; though it was just then raging at Marseilles— Stockjobbing—he barely touches upon this and says he purposely avoids enlarging upon it— Yet of the four calamities specified by him this was the only one which they could justly impute to themselves— Saurin and Massillon were cotemporaries—both Frenchmen—one a Protestant refugee; the other a Roman Catholic—and each considered the other, as one of the greatest sins of the Age— I looked again over the Volumes of Massillon for the invective upon William the 3d. and the malediction of the Protestants, without finding it—but I recognized again numerous admirable passages in Massillon, which I had marked, when reading him in 1809–10 and 11.— I always admire the boldness of his reproof and the severity of his rebukes upon the vices of Courts and Courtiers— I continued also the draught of a Report to the Board of Overseers, upon the disturbances at the University— This is a subject the importance of which grows upon me as I proceed, and the earnestness in writing grows in proportion
4. V. Monday.

Alpheus Spear was here this morning, and gave me another Bill, for the one which had been returned to me as doubtful. He spoke also about the expiration of his Lease of the Mount Wollaston farm, and of his wish for the renewal of it— I promised to go down there next Thursday afternoon at four O’Clock, and talk with him about it— In visiting my garden and Nursery—I find every day new matter of observation— The vegetation of the second shoots of the chesnut Oaks has ceased— That of the red and English Oaks has not yet closed. A very promising Peach tree, of those which I set out in the Garden last October, has until within the last fortnight appeared to be dead; but is now putting out shoots— A remnant of root left in the Summer house cellar, from one of the elms taken up and transplanted last October has thrown out a vigorous shoot, and led me to the enquiry whether upon transplanting a young elm, you cannot always leave root enough to bear another tree; and if you can of elm, why not of fruit trees of all kinds—an enquiry the result of which may be useful— I had requested yesterday Isaac Hull Adams, who told me he should go to Boston this morning, to see my Son Charles and tell him that his mother had arrived, which he did, and Charles came out before dinner— Ebenezer Adams was here this afternoon: to enquire if I wanted hay or wood, or a share and note of the Quincy Canal—but I have no means— The day was cool, though the Sun was intense— I continued writing for the report of the Committee of Overseers.
5. IV:30. Tuesday.

I received this morning an answer from Governor Lincoln, to the Letter which I wrote him on the first instt.— He names next Friday 11 O’Clock A.M. for the Meeting of the Committee—declines preparing a report and returns the Statement of President Quincy— I wrote by the mail to Coll. B. T. Pickman, Dr John Codman, and Alexander H Everett, to notify them of the Meeting on Friday: and I also wrote answers to Joseph Meigs of Mattapoisett, and to Stephen C Phillips of Salem— This brought me in arrears of other writing, but not of the most essential— I visited my garden and nursery where I found the heat of the Sun intolerable— Of my young seedlings which were unknown, I now recognize the holly— My seedling Strawberries both in the garden and nursery are putting forth their creepers— The white oak bud, in the red Oak stock does not take— I sheltered several seedling cherries and apples of the present year with shingles.— I stake with twigs of willow every day some new seedling the progress of which I wish to observe— Observation multiplies upon me, as my seedlings annually increase; and with it, the pleasure of observing— One step further is needful—that is to make observation profitable—to derive fruit from observation At noon, the tide being high, and the day of the new moon, I bathed with Charles at the Creek wharf and swam about five minutes— Isaac H. Adams dined with us— The day was again one of high Summer heat
6. IV.45 Wednesday.

I wrote a reply to the Letter of Governor Lincoln— Walter Hellen went with Isaac H. Adams to Cohasset and Nantasket beach. Charles after Breakfast returned to Boston— I visited my Garden and Nursery, but was driven back by the radiance of the Sun to the House. The Sun is killing every day some of my new sprung seedling trees— Those in the Pots are drooping with drought, so that to save them, I shall be obliged to Water the Pots— I transferred some of them to the Alley fronting my chamber windows— I found a seedling walnut up in a stand before the old Pear trees
observed new shoots from one of the willow stakes which I set out a few days since— Strip’d away two nests of Palmer worms from the white Mulberries, and stuck down the remainder of the Branch at the West end of the garden— Henry Hardwick came to enquire again about the purchase of a quarter of Acre of my land at the Salt-marsh—part of the Mount Wollaston farm— I told him if the weather would permit, I should go down there to-morrow afternoon, and he promised to meet me there— About 1. O’Clock I bathed and swam at the Creek wharf— Met there Mr Marden with his Lighter, the Washington of Boston, which he has purchased, and is fitting up to send granite to Boston. The wharf is covered with the Stone— John Q. Adams my nephew and his Sister Elizabeth were here this Evening— Saw the moon descending in the west second day— Much annoyed with mosquito’s— I hear my Grand daughter Mary Louisa read every morning—and I am still writing on the report to the Board of Overseers.
7. IV.15. Thursday.

The heat and the Musquitos drove me from my bed to another chamber, without securing me much repose— I began to water the Pots in which I have young seedling fruit trees— In one of them seven trees from as many seeds of one dwarf Apple— I could stay but a short time in the Nursery, from the intensity of the Sun; and it was to observe—first the almost certain destruction of every seedling of the present Season, constantly exposed to the Sun; and secondly the like failure of almost every plant that comes up wholly shaded— Such is the case with the Apples, Pears, Cherries, Peaches and Walnuts, planted on the Northwest side of my Nursery Gate, and under the Elms at the bottom of the Nursery— Many have come up: but none of them thrive— To keep a plant alive through its first season, it should be alternately shaded and exposed to the Sun, morning and afternoon— Between one and two O’Clock before dinner, I bathed and swam at the wharf—but the excessive heat prevented me from going after dinner to the Mount Wollaston farm— I made an exertion to finish the draught of a report to the Board of Overseers, but without success— I saw in the Newspapers an account of the death of Judge William Johnson of South-Carolina, a judge of the Supreme Court of the United States— He died in the very act of submitting to a surgical operation, by Dr Valentine Mott at New-York— I read a few pages of the Memoirs of Dangeau— They consist of curious trifles at the Court of Louis 14—who was a sort of great man—a compound of great virtues and vices; and like most other great men a bundle of inconsistencies— Small men, in their sphere are much the same— Absolute consistency is not an attribute of human nature, and to charge a man with it seems to be little more than accusing him of not being immortal.
8. IV. Friday.

I finished early this morning my draught of a Report to the Board of Overseers— William Spear called, and I gave him a list of my pews in the Meeting-house, with the prices annexed to each pew, and the rent at ten per Cent on the price of the pew for a year; and proportionally for one Quarter of a year—declining to let less than one pew, or for less than one Quarter— I went to Boston, with my wife, Walter Hellen, and my Grand-child Mary-Louisa. We went first to Charles’s house, and there saw him. his wife had come in with her two children, for their Grandmother to see them— She
returned to Quincy before dinner with Walter and Mary-Louisa— I attended at Coll. B. T. Pickman’s at eleven O’Clock— The other members of the Committee, Governor Lincoln, Dr. John Codman and Alexander H. Everett—soon came in; and I read to them, the Report that I had prepared in performance of the commission from the board of Overseers— It took me an hour and a quarter to read it, and it did not meet the approbation of any other member of the Committee— They all thought it much too severe upon the Students— Governor Lincoln, was entirely opposed to the prosecution of the Students in the Court of Law— He was also opposed to a Resolution recommending that the President should conditionally cause the Prosecution to be withdrawn— He was opposed to every thing proposed in my report; but had nothing of his own to propose. Mr Everett was equally opposed to the prosecution at Law, but was in favour of the Resolution recommending that the prosecution should be withdrawn— He also thought the Report, not only too severe upon the Circular of the Senior Class, but even unjust, because it was treating young men scarcely arrived at the age of discretion, as if they were entirely responsible men— He thought besides that although the charges in the Circular were very improper as coming from undergraduates, they were upon the whole substantially well founded— That Mr Quincy was a man very wanting in discretion; of which he had given many proofs— He specified, his proposal when a member of Congress to impeach Mr Jefferson for which he could not obtain a second—and also his conduct to him last Winter upon an enquiry respecting the conferring a degree of L.L.D. on President Jackson, without duly notifying the members of the board of Overseers— Mr Everett said he had then prepared a conciliatory proposition; and went to President Quincy and proposed reading it to him; upon which he said to him—“I wont talk with you about it”— He thought the report therefore incorrect in defending Mr Quincy from the charge of indiscretion— That was his character, and his Administration at the University was also very unpopular—as evidence of which he had received a Letter from a friend in a remote part of the State, who noticing his (Everett’s) appointment as a member of this Committee, says “cannot you contrive to get us rid of Mr Quincy”— I replied that as to Mr Quincy’s general character for discretion, I did not think it a subject of enquiry or report by this Committee—but I had undertaken to prove and I thought had proved that there had been no want of discretion in his conduct in relation to these transactions— That I believed neither Mr Quincy, nor any other public man of his standing could be exempt from some charge of indiscretion in the course of a long life, and if there was such a man, he was none the better on that account— That discretion was a negative virtue, perhaps possessed in higher perfection by knaves than by honest men and that if the object of this Committee, was to contrive to get rid of Mr Quincy, I was not a proper person to be a member of it; as I could give no countenance to any such design. Dr Codman said he was sorry to hear Mr Everett, quote this expression from the Letter of his friend— He added that he himself was friendly to Mr Quincy; and preferred him to all the other persons who had been mentioned for the Office at the time of his appointment— That he approved generally, and very highly the substance of my report; but
he wished it might be modified, in the severity of its Language respecting the misconduct of the Students; and that it should avoid the expression of any opinion, respecting the propriety of the prosecution at Law— Mr Pickman declared his concurrence in all the opinions expressed in the report, and only wished that its severity should be softened— Dr Codman said that it had been evidently written under some excitement, and personal feeling at the treatment of President Quincy by the Students and that a revisal might take off some of its sharpness— I admitted that it had been written under excitement, of indignation at the charges in the Circular of the Senior Class against President Quincy, who had been my intimate friend for nearly fifty years; without interruption even by the most earnest and ardent opposition of political opinions— He had been my unwavering friend, without a moment’s interruption; and I had the most unbounded confidence in his integrity— But I declared myself not at-all tenacious of my report, either as a whole, or of any parcel of it— I would alter, amend or entirely withdraw it at the pleasure of the Committee.— Dr Codman proposed that Governor Lincoln and Mr Everett should be a Subcommittee to revise and amend my report to be considered at an adjourned meeting of the Committee next Thursday— Governor Lincoln said it would not be in his power to attend a meeting next week, and he shewed a great disinclination to take any charge upon himself in this affair; expressing a doubt whether he should even attend the adjourned meeting of the overseers; and repeating that the President could not arrest the prosecution upon the Indictment, if he would— He disclaimed all ill will towards President Quincy, and said he had constantly been under the impression, until very recently, that his administration at the University was very popular.— I said I knew well that the prosecution upon the Indictment could not be arrested but with the consent of the Attorney for the Government— But as it had been commenced at the instance of the College faculty, I had no doubt, a noli prosequi would be entered upon an intimation from the President that it was desired— Mr Codman then proposed that Mr Everett and I should be the Subcommittee to revise the report for an adjourned meeting of the Committee next Thursday— To this I assented and it was so voted by the Committee. Mr Everett took with him my report, the President’s Statement, the Circular of the Senior Class, and a copy of the College Laws, received this morning while the Committee were in Session— Upon these papers, Mr Everett is to prepare his report, and communicate it to me by next Monday; and we are to report again to the Committee at Coll. Pickman’s house next Thursday morning at 11. O’Clock— It is possible that Mr Everett and I may agree on this point but not probable— His principles in relation to the subject are entirely different and indeed opposite to mine— His object is a marked expression of disapprobation by the Overseers of the prosecution at Law, and only such censure upon the riotous Students, as to leave on the public mind the impression that in the main they were right— He distinctly avowed that opinion this day—His object is to “get rid of Mr Quincy[”], and most probably to take his place himself. He will improve this adventure to that end, with all his ability which is great, and with all his Address which is small— For his manners are not more captivating
than those of Mr Quincy himself— I deeply sorrow that I am obliged to take any part in this controversy; and the more so because in wishing to sustain my friend Quincy, I am fearful of injuring myself without benefiting him: and because I am much perplexed how to support him most efficaciously— I distrust my own discretion in the endeavour to sustain his, and am above all anxious not to aggravate, where I would assuage— The meeting of the Committee adjourned after two O’Clock, and I remained and dined with Coll. Pickman, his wife and her Mother Mrs William Smith— At 4. O’Clock Gillet of the Quincy Stage called there for me, and I returned home with four other Passengers all females, one of whom was Mrs Mary Dawes, daughter of Mr John Greenleaf— In the Evening Isaac H. and J. Q. Adams 2d. were here.
9. V. Saturday

Henry Wilson heretofore a Seaman in the Navy, and before that, during the last War with Great Britain a Soldier in the Army came this morning and said he wished me to obtain a pension for him next winter at Washington— He produced and left with me a certificate of his discharge from the naval Service by order of Commodore Isaac Chauncey at New-York dated the 2d. of October 1830. and said the cause of his discharge was disability occasioned by a rupture which he had suffered in working on board the Brandywine Frigate on the first of the preceding January— He said he now had on the Truss which the Surgeon put on him at the time when the rupture happened, but he had no evidence to prove either the rupture or the disability. He said the fact must be noted both on the Journal kept on board of the Brandywine, and in the Correspondence at the Navy Department—but he spoke in the most disrespectful terms of Chauncey, who he said was a coward, and to whom he represented himself as having spoken insultingly— He was so much inflamed with liquor that I did not much discourse with him nor ascertain the cause of his animosity against Chauncey; but I inferred from what he said that he had been discharged for his insolence. He told me that for his military service in the late War he had a Land Warrant N. 12638. for 160 Acres of Land in Illinois 9 North Range 3. East, that his Captains name was Tyler and his Coll. Alexr Macomb now the Major General— I promised to make application for him for a Pension, but said I thought there would be a demand of evidence to his disability— He said if there was and I would write and inform him of it, he would go to New-York where he believed he could obtain the Evidence, and then go on to Washington himself. He said he belonged to this town—had formerly been a tenant of my farm at the foot of Penn’s Hill, and was now working at the Stone cutting business— I visited my Garden and Nursery— Saw three Walnut seedlings just up from the ground— The two last years beeches each unfolding a leaf— Red Oaks yet unfolding new leaves— Seedling Strawberries up, under Charles’s Elm the two seedling apples that I took out and transplanted last week are dying; but the one left has put out a new upward shoot I spread a shovel full of garden earth over the patch before my chamber windows where peaches pears, apples and grapes planted last autumn have come up— I wrote nothing but the journal of yesterday. Walter Hellen went on a fishing party to Squantum with Isaac H. and J. Q. Adams, and did
not return till after dinner— My wife took tea at Mrs T. B. Adams’s, and I went there after an evening visit to Mr Edward Miller— Mrs Miller is at Plymouth. I met Alpheus Spear and promised to call on him at the farm next Wednesday afternoon at 4 O’Clock, unless prevented by heat or rain
10. V. Sunday

Heard Mr William Elliot of Washington, in the morning from 2. Corinthians 4.18. [“]While we look not at the things which are seen, but at the things where are not seen—for the things which are seen are temporal; but the things which are not seen are eternal”—and in the afternoon from Revelation 3.15. [“]I know thy works that thou art neither cold nor hot: I would thou wert cold or hot” I saw this young man graduated at the Columbian College at Washington in December 1831. His mother is a daughter of my old friend Thomas Dawes He has a small person, and a small voice, but his performances were quite respectable his Sermons well-written and delivered with Spirit and propriety— That of the morning was ingenious in tracing the connection between the habitual contemplation of eternal things, not seen, and a virtuous and happy life— Walter went with me in the morning, and Mary Louisa in the afternoon— I read the 11th. Sermon of the 5th. Volume of Saurin, upon the Eternity of God—said to have been delivered in the French Church at Rotterdam the first Sunday of the year 1724— It gave me no satisfaction The subject is above human comprehension, and so he declares it to be— I can follow no train of reasoning on this topic a single step without stumbling— My own existence and the world around me, bespeaks an intelligent first cause, not temporary— The authentic history of the human species is traceable back not more than 4–5—or at most 6000 years—a drop of water to an Ocean, in comparison with a conceivable portion of time— But eternity has neither past nor future, while time has no present— Eternity cannot be measured by time— The phenomena of physical nature, would seem to indicate that matter is not destructible, but only changeable— It is unceasing mutability— Eternity is immutable. I must wait for light, and hearken to human reason upon more comprehensible things— I read over also Massillon’s Panegyric of John the Baptist, delivered at Sceaux, before the Duke and Duchess du Maine— The duke du Maine was a legitimated natural Son of Louis 14 by Madame de Montespan, and some of the most eloquent and indignant passages of this discourse, are in exaltation of the character of the Baptist for the fearless Spirit with which he reproved Herod for having his brother’s wife— Well might Louis 14 say to Massillon that other preachers delighted him but he made him discontented with himself— After all I read no Sermons with so much admiration as Massillon’s. Mr Beale and his daughter were here this Evening, and I. H. Adams dined with us
11. V. Monday.

Isaac H. Adams called me from my Garden visit, to take leave, his second furlough being about to expire; and he on his way to return to West-Point— I took Kirk, to begin the weeding of my Garden and Nursery. I replaced two seedling Currant bushes of the third year, the roots of which had been nearly screwed out of the ground by the frost— After weeding the patch opposite the Summer house cellar, I found in it a seedling white Oak of the second year, with the most beautiful form of the white Oak leaf—
Found two nests of ugly worms, large and small upon a young Apple-tree, at the South-west corner of the garden— The seedlings are all drooping with heat and drought. Some of the red Oaks still unfold their shoots. I answered a Letter from the Revd George Allen, the author of the Papers dated Heart of the Commonwealth, published last Autumn and of which he has sent me a pamphlet copy— Mrs. Adams had a morning visit from Mrs S. Dexter— Charles came out from Boston. In the afternoon I rode with Mrs Adams and Walter round by Solomon Thayer’s, and took a number of twigs from his Norton Quincy Apple-tree—those which I had on the 24th. of last Month, being too early in the Season for the bud to be formed. Returning home in the Evening I had them put into a bucket of water
12. IV:30 Tuesday.

Walter Hellen went to Boston this morning to take leave of I. H. Adams, and returned in the afternoon Stage. I visited my garden and Nursery, and commenced a series of written observations in my old Memorandum Book upon the planting and progress of my seedling plants— I did begin such observations in 1832 September, but continued them only one week— Those few minutes are even now useful to me— I find it difficult to recur to those made in other books. The heat of the Sun again drove me into the house— My nephew namesake came to invite me to take the bath with him; but I had taken it at half past five this morning alone— Marden’s lighter was then coming up to the Creek, but grounded just off the wharf. I sent to ask Price Greenleaf to come and bud some Apple trees for me, and he came; but a thunder-shower and company intervened— Alexander Townsend and Mr Courtney, keeper of a female School at Charleston South-Carolina came and spent the afternoon and early Evening with us. Townsend invited me to dine with him at the Marlborough Hotel, his residence to-morrow. The day was gone, and I had done nothing— So it is with every day—
13. V. Wednesday— Boston—back to Quincy

Charles’s daughter Louisa Catherine was this day three years old— I sent this morning to Mr Price Greenleaf requesting him to come and bud some trees for me— He came and budded five seedling Apple socks in my Nursery with buds of the Norton Quincy Apple from Solomon Thayer. Two of them are of the row next to the Nectarine tree at the north-end of the Nursery. Charles went to Boston and Medford, and I went to Boston with Wilson— Called at Alexander H. Everett’s house, and he gave me the report and Resolutions which he had prepared for the Committee of the Board of Overseers, as a substitute for mine— The report is a mere caption to the Resolutions with an excuse for not presenting an Address to the Public, on the ground of wanting time to prepare it with due deliberation; and asking leave to sit again for that purpose— After some short discussion I agreed to take Mr Everett’s Report and Resolutions and examine them, and report them to the Committee for consideration to-morrow morning— I expressed very strongly my opinion against the presentation in the Circular of the Senior Class to be
exempted from prosecution at Law, for property destroyed, belonging to the University— Mr Everett thought the prosecution in this instance was unpopular— I said I believed the pretension of the Students would ultimately prove much more unpopular; but that I looked not to popularity, but to Justice— He said there were three members of the Committee against the Prosecution— I thought, only two— He claimed Dr Codman, whom I considered as only doubting— Everett then asked me to consider the claim of the Students to exemption from prosecution—upon the ground of youth and inexperience—which I promised to do. At 11. O’Clock I attended a Meeting of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences— There were less than ten members present, and the only communications received were acceptances of election of members— I had at the Statute Meeting of last August proposed the Revd N. L. Frothingham as a Member— I found on the Book of nominations that this one had been acted on the 27th. of May last, and on enquiry, was informed by Mr Treadwell, the corresponding Secretary that he had wanted one vote of three fourths of the ballots and was therefore not admitted— Treadwell said Mr Frothingham had been proposed once before. Dr Bigelow asked me if I was acquainted with the merits of Dr Jones, heretofore of the Patent Office— I was not. He said he was Editor of the Journal of the Franklin Institute. The meeting was not more than a quarter of an hour long, and on the whole did the most nothing of any meeting of a Scientific body that I ever attended. After it was over, I spoke to Mr Bowditch who is a member of the Corporation of the University, about the prosecution of the three Sophomores by Indictment before the Court of Common Pleas for the County of Middlesex— He said the measure had been unanimously approved by the Corporation, and also by Judge Jackson, who had been a member of the Board, but had lately resigned— He said too that the prosecution was not a novelty, but that there had been repeated instances of it for the last fifty years, though never carried through to judgment— He said that thirteen of the Students had testified at Concord without hesitation, and two after making some objection, and having the Law explained to them— I went to Charles’s Office and remained there till near three. Purchased for Mary Louisa, the Dairy and Cowslip, and Pierpont’s introduction to the National Reader— At three I went to the Marlborough Hotel, and dined with Alexander Townsend. This House belongs to him and is kept, by a Mr and Mrs Wyatt who kept the house at Dover New-Hampshire where we lodged last September— I saw Mrs Wyatt in her parlour— The company at dinner were chiefly classmates of Mr Townsend, with the addition of Lieutent Governor Armstrong, Franklin Dexter, and Mr Blake a lawyer from Bangor, and Dr J. M. Wainwright, now rector of Trinity Church—Boston— I had ordered Wilson to call for me in the Chaise at 6. and at the dusk of Evening I got home— We had Evening visits from Mr Beale and his three daughters, and from Mr and Mrs Emmons their relatives. There is great excitement and agitation in Boston and the neighbourhood on account of the destruction, on Monday night by a mob, of a Convent of Ursulines—Nuns at Charlestown— The immediate and ostensible cause of the outrage, was a rumour circulated among the people, that a young woman who had taken the veil, and then ran away, had been carried back and was detained there, by force— There is a singular inertness in the public authorities
14. IV:30. Thursday— Boston and back to Quincy.

I planted this morning my two Apricot Stones, and went to Boston in the Carriage, which took out Charles’s wife, and two children, Louisa-Catherine, and John Quincy— At 11. O’Clock, I went to Coll. B. T. Pickman’s and there met with him, Dr John Codman and Alexander H. Everett the Committee of the Overseers of Harvard University, with the exception of Governor Lincoln who was absent— We discussed the Report and Resolutions proposed by Mr Everett; and finally modified them so as to make a patchwork, to which we all agreed—asking to be discharged from the duty of preparing an Address to the Public— At the suggestion of other members of the Committee, I promised to send Governor Lincoln a copy of our Report and Resolutions and if he should approve them, which he will not I am to present the report as agreed to by the Committee, unanimously— For this unanimity I have given up all my own peculiar opinions, and the full exposition of them in the draught of a report that I had prepared— I have had some struggle in my own mind, and question whether I ought to yield, on points so important and so clear— I finally concluded that it would be most prudent to give way— There is only one member of the Committee, who fully agrees with me, and there are two most pointedly in opposition to my opinions— While I was at Coll. Pickmans Mr George Odiorne came, and said he had been with Mr Henry Dana Ward of New-York, out to Quincy to see me; and hearing that I was in the City, they had immediately returned. Mr Ward was very desirous of having some conversation with me, and Mr Odiorne asked if I would call at his House 43 Hancock Street— I went there from Coll Pickman’s on the adjournment of the Committee at one— Dr Parkman had invited me to dine with him at two: I had accepted conditionally the invitation, and desired Charles if I should not be at his Office at one, to go out with him, to give notice to Gillet driver of the Quincy Stage to call for me at Dr Parkmans at 4— At Mr Odiorne’s I met Mr Ward, and found the subject on which they wished to converse with me was Antimasonic Politics— Mr Wards ostensible object was to persuade the Anti-masons of Massachusetts to be prepared to nominate Francis Granger, for next President of the United-States, and to agree that a National Antimasonic Convention should be called to meet in June 1835 for that purpose— There is a collateral question, who shall be voted for as Governor of Massachusetts by the Antimasons of the State— Mr Odiorne said they could not possibly vote for John Davis; but I told him I believed the Antimasons of Worcester County would do so— He spoke of Mr Bailey—of Heman Lincoln—of S. Lathrop, and of Judge Morton, for whom he thought it was hardly possible they should— I told him I believed it must be soon reduced to that—Davis or Morton; for if they should set up a Candidate of their own they would be certainly and totally defeated— And as to the nomination of Francis Granger for President of the United States; they would do well, first to try their hands at electing him Governor of New York— If they should succeed in that, and if Mr Ritner should be chosen Governor of Pennsylvania, then there might be a reasonable formation of a prospect upon which Mr Granger might be brought forward as a Candidate for the Presidency.— For the present I thought the project impracticable— This
conversation continued upwards of an hour, and I found it necessary rather to infer the object of Mr Ward’s present visit to Boston from the whole tenor of his observations than from the direct proposition which he made— My inference was that Mr Ward’s mission was to take the soundings of Antimasonry in Massachusetts in behalf of Martin van Buren; and that the first step towards it is to turn over the Antimasonic votes here to Marcus Morton, for the Office of Governor.— I dined with Dr George Parkman who urgently invited me to dine with him again next Thursday; the day when the Overseers of Harvard University are to meet— There were this day at the dinner judge Peter O. Thacher and his wife, who is a Sister of Mrs Parkman, Mr Robert G. Shaw and Daniel Parkman— At four O’Clock Gillet came and took me up in the Quincy Stage, and before 6 I was at home, travelling with five women, four baby children, and two other men, and two outside passengers, all except Mr Ibrahim Bartlett Strangers to me.— I found Charles, his wife and two children at my House— The Evening was damp and sultry, and there was a long heavy thunder shower after we were in bed.
15. V. Friday.

The day, as for business was consumed in bringing up the Diary record of yesterday, and the day before, and without finishing— I visited my garden and Nursery morning and afternoon. The weeding of the Nursery was nearly finished, by Kirk, and a man whom he employed to assist him— I planted 12 mazzard steeped cherries in two places repeating an experiment which I have made several years successively, but for want of recollection or record from one Season to another, remaining without ascertained result— Mr E. Price Greenleaf came this afternoon, and budded for me three Pear stock Suckers in the Garden, and three Apple-stocks in the Nursery— He took off the cotton yarn bandages, from eight budded Cherry Stocks, five in the patch opposite my old Walnut tree, four white and three black-hearts, and three blackhearts in the patch opposite the Nursery gate— Found on one of my tall red Oaks a number of small white worms which have eaten off the green surface of the leaves, and left them like sheets of transparent brown paper— Not a day passes but I discover some new insect, worm or caterpillar, preying upon my seedling plants— Mr Greenleaf budded also three of my sucker Plum stocks. Mr James H. and Mrs Foster paid us an afternoon visit.
16 IV:30 Saturday.

Charles went to Boston, and returned to dinner— The day was cool, and I spent three hours of the morning in my Garden and Nursery. Planted a row of Currants, before the fence at the North end of the Nursery— I continue to set out slips of the willow, and they still put forth shoots— I emptied Earthen Pots 5 and 7. filled them with fresh Earth, and planted in 5. six steeped cherries— In the afternoon I rode on Horseback to the Mount Wollaston farm, saw Alpheus Spear and agreed to call upon him again next Wednesday, should it be fair and cool— I then went up the Bent’s point road, and returned by the Braintree and Weymouth Turnpike—about 7 miles— This is the most healthy exercise that I could take, but I cannot indulge myself with it.
My gardening and my ride consumed almost the whole day. I wrote a short Letter to Governor Lincoln, and made out a fair copy of the Report and Resolutions agreed upon by the Committee of the Board of Overseers last Thursday— Mr Beale and his daughter Ann, and Mr and Mrs Emmons were here in the Evening.
17. V:15. Sunday.

Heard Mr William Elliot, in the morning from Romans 1.7. “called to be Saints” and in the afternoon from 2. Corinthians 4.4. “the glorious gospel of Christ” a continuation of the same subject— The call to be Saints was a call to holiness, that is to virtue, to purity of life, and it was and is addressed equally to all Christians— This too was the glorious gospel of Christ— In the afternoon discourse there was an exposition of the doctrine of regeneration, as founded upon the declarations of Jesus Christ to Nicodemus— The regeneration of the Spirit; one of the passages in Scripture, of which it would seem as if the perversion was scarcely possible—yet one of those which have been most monstrously perverted— Captain Josiah Bass put into my hands a subscription paper for a genealogical book by Mr Thayer of Dedham, concerning certain families in this neighbourhood— I subscribed for a copy of the Book and returned the paper to Captain Bass in the afternoon. Mr E. Price Greenleaf invited me to visit his Nursery this afternoon, but I was prevented by rain— I read the 12th. and last Sermon of the 5th. Volume of Saurin, upon a Communion day— It is a Discourse altogether of reproof against those who took the Sacrament unworthily— Charging many of his auditory upon their consciences with the commission of that Offence, and expatiating upon its enormity— I read also an Oration, delivered by Mr John Holmes late a Senator of the United States from the State of Maine— It was delivered on the last 4th. of July at China, in the County of Kennebec, and contains a very severe review of the measures of the present Administration of the federal Government— And I began a Letter in answer to one lately received from Mr Madison.
18. V Monday.

Morning visit to my Garden and Nursery— Abridged by visitors— Henry Hardwick, who came again about the strip of Land he wants to buy— I told him I had promised to go down to the farm Wednesday afternoon if the weather should be fair. I found in the garden one Hickory newly up—and staked out several twigs of White Mulberry— Transplanted four seedling Apple-trees, of this year in the western patch next to the road, so as to make a row of twelve there— The two that I transplanted the second of this month, though their top leaves dried up and fell off, are alive and looking well— This has encouraged me to repeat the experiment— And I now keep a plantation Diary. Morning visits from Mr Bailey, and Lieutt. Governor Armstrong. The latter mentioned that the resignation by Mr Edward Everett of his Seat in the House of Representatives of the United States was announced in this Morning’s Papers.
Mr Bailey thought the Antimasons could not support Mr John Davis for re-election as Governor of the Commonwealth, notwithstanding his recent correspondence, with Mr Pliny Merrick— I fear they will not, but told him I believed he would be re-elected and that the Antimasons would finally divide, and vote, part for Davis and part for Morton— This I apprehend will be the end of Antimasonry in this Commonwealth. This afternoon I went with Charles to Mr T. Greenleaf’s and visited his Son E. Price Greenleaf’s Plantation Nursery near the Brook— There are in his enclosure many old trees; and of his young plants he has flowers as well as fruit trees— He has not much variety; and the Tulip tree, is his most thrifty plant— Towards Sunset I rode on horseback to the cross road this side of Neponset Bridge, across to Gulliver’s Brook and home; about six Miles— It is six years, since I rode almost every day on horseback through one Summer— I find myself now much less able to bear the fatigue— My day was idle— Charles’s birth day— He is 27— A short time to look back
19. V. Tuesday.

Charles and Walter Hellen went to Boston, and returned to dine. I was called from my visit in my Garden to President Quincy, who returned last Saturday from his excursion to the State of New-York. He seems to me, not yet adequately prepared to meet the occasions immediately before him, and repeats what I have heard him say several times before of his astonishment at finding all the young men, whom he had treated with the greatest kindness combining in the Senior Class against him— He said he should not have been more surprized if his two Sons had come into his Study and knock’d him down— This is almost identically the saying of Pompey the great, when asked what if Caesar should cross the Rubicon— He repeated also the reminiscence of the Proctor who was with him when Barnwall of South-Carolina, came to his Study and announced himself as from the nullification State— It was to him and on that occasion that Mr Quincy told him he expected he would give trouble to the faculty, and that he made some remark upon the licentiousness of Southern Scholars, which this young man has perverted into an invidious charge against him— I read to Mr Quincy the Report and Resolutions, which the Committee of the Overseers have agreed to report to the Board, and told him that I had prepared a long Report, which no other member of the Committee had entirely approved, and to which Governor Lincoln, and Alexander H. Everett were so strongly opposed that I had thought best to withdraw it— Mr Quincy was not satisfied with the third Resolution proposed by the Committee and appeared exceedingly averse to any recommendation to discontinue the Prosecution of the Indictments, against the three Sophomores at Concord; unless they would plead that they would not contend with the Commonwealth— He said that two of them had been dismissed from the University and therefore could not now submit it to its Laws— This I did not know, and think it does not appear from the Statement of the President, or the two previous Circulars of the Faculty— I told him that the third Resolution, was not in the form that I had proposed and that I had assented
to it only that a report should be presented for consideration of the Board, to which all the members present of the Committee could agree— I had thus far yielded my own opinion, but should readily acquiesce in a different modification of the Resolution, or even to postpone it till after Commencement— I requested him particularly to come prepared with all the precedents which had heretofore occurred of prosecutions at Law, against Students, which had been commenced, and with authentic testimony to what stage the prosecutions had been carried; and he said he would— I fear that from some of the peculiarities of his temper, and from a hesitancy in his elocution the Students have lost the feeling of reverence for his character which is essential to the preservation of authority; and that it will be difficult if possible for him to recover it— The very familiarity of personal intercourse with him and his family which he has allowed to the Students beyond all former example has I believe contributed to weaken his influence over them. After he left me I returned to my Garden, which exercised me for another hour— I resumed this afternoon the Discourse on the Life and Character of La Fayette.
20. V. Wednesday.

Visited my Garden and Nursery, from which I had a superfluity of Stones carried away— I took off the lowest bough, from the Stake button wood—which has the most rapid growth of any of my plantations, and separated it into four twigs which I staked out, as also a crooked slip of willow—and I transplanted from the Garden to the Nursery, three roots of my Garden wild Strawberries— There was a drizzling rain which shortened my labour in the Garden; and drove me to the House— It became afterwards a plentiful rain with a cold Northwest wind. The tax-gatherer from Braintree came a second time for taxes for the years 1831 and 1832. with a specification by two of the Assessors that it was partly for Pine-hill, and partly for Land that was Norton Quincy’s.— I desired him to ascertain from the Assessors how much of it was for Pine-hill, and that I would pay—but as I had not an inch of Land in Braintree that ever belonged to Norton Quincy, I could not pay taxes upon any such land— He said it was too much trouble for him to go to the Assessors again, for that he should receive only eight Cents for collecting the tax, and intimated that he would sell my land. I called John Kirk to hear what I said to him, and repeated that if he would ascertain from the Assessors how much of the tax was upon my land I would immediately pay it, and that as for the rest he must do as he thought proper— In the House my Diary and index and La Fayette occupied me for the remainder of the day. In the Evening we played whist, and I received by a special Messenger, a Letter requesting me to bring with me to the Meeting of the Board of Overseers to-morrow the draught of a Report which I had prepared, but which the Committee did not accept. I had filed it among my papers not intending to take it with me, but shall comply with Mr Quincy’s request. Discretion would perhaps advise me to keep myself aloof from this new subject of public controversy, but a sense of duty to the Country and my friendship for Mr Quincy must be my guides.
21. IV:15 Thursday.— Boston— Overseers Meeting.

The morn was lowering, with rain, and Charles not inclining to go to Boston I went in the Stage, and measured by time the distance of the cross road from the corner near the Stone Blacksmith’s Shop, and Gulliver’s Brook in Milton to its issue, on the Neponset Bridge road— It is a few rods short of two miles—and Gillet’s average travelling is at the rate of 7 1/2 minutes to a Mile, or eight miles an hour— Arriving at Charles’s Office, I met Dr. Parkman as I alighted, and he reminded me of my engagement to dine with him— At ten I attended at the Council chamber the Meeting of the Overseers of Harvard University— But Dr Pierce the Secretary did not attend the Meeting: he had not sent the Book of Records of the proceedings of the Board, and had advertised the Meeting for eleven O’Clock— There were not a sufficient number of members present to open the Meeting, and an hour of time was lost— When opened, presided by Lieutt. Governor Armstrong, he called for the Report of the Committee on the degrees to be conferred. Alexander H. Everett Chairman of that Committee not being present, the Report of the Committee on President Quincy’s Statement was called for, and I read and handed it in, at the table. Richard Sullivan rose, and said he had expected a different sort of Report, and wished to know why the Committee had asked to be discharged from the instruction to prepare an address to the Public— He was not satisfied with the Report presented, and could not give his assent to the third Resolution— He wished to know why the Committee had made such a Report as that which had been read— I then stated that there had been two Meetings of the Committee— That I had first sent to Governor Lincoln, President Quincy’s Statement, and a copy of the commission and instruction to the Committee requesting him to prepare a report to be submitted to the Committee— He had returned the President’s Statement, and agreed to attend a meeting of the Committee; but declined preparing the Report, and expressed his regret at having been placed on the Committee, which owing to his being much engaged in other business, was much to his inconvenience— I had been thus under the necessity of preparing a Report, according to my own impressions upon the subject, which accorded altogether with those expressed by Mr Sullivan— This report I had read to the Committee at their first Meeting, and it had unfortunately not met the approbation of any one of my Colleagues on the Committee— Two of the members, Governor Lincoln, and Mr Everett were decidedly opposed to some of its principles— A third doubted of the expediency of the prosecution at Law, of the Students, and all objected to the severity of animadversion, in the Report upon the conduct of the Students, and particularly upon the Circular of the Senior Class. It was not for me under these Circumstances to press the Report upon the Committee. I accordingly withdrew it, and afterwards, with Mr A H. Everett, and then with the other members of the Committee except Governor Lincoln, at a second Meeting, assented to the Report and Resolutions which had been read, to bring the subject in proper form before the Board for their consideration. I had at the direction of the Committee, sent a copy of this Report to Governor Lincoln, and had this morning received from him an answer to my Letter, declaring his approbation of the first and third Resolutions, and his dissent from the second— The third having been now so modified, as to have removed his objections.
Coll. Pickman stated that his views had in general concurred with mine. That he should have preferred my report to that which had been presented, and had wished only for the softening of some of its expressions— Dr Codman said that he too approved of my report in the main, but had entertained doubts with regard to the Prosecutions at Law, and had agreed to the presented report for the sake of unanimity— Alexander H. Everett made a Speech of near half an hour in favour of the presented report— He regretted the movement of Mr Sullivan which had called forth the Statement by me of the proceedings in the Committee—and gave the reasons of his disapprobation of the prosecution at Law— He thought the Government of the University stood towards the Students in loco parentis, and it was not for them to institute against them prosecutions at Law— He likened the relations between teachers and pupils to those between father and Son—between Husband and wife; between guardian and ward, and thought that wherever there was a personal and intimate relation between a mere trespasser and the cardinal Law of the State, he thought the party offended should not be the prosecutor— He enlarged upon this position with some ingenuity and earnestness, but without apparent impression upon any member present. He objected with great warmth against making the Resolution recommending the withdrawal of the prosecutions contingent upon the entire restoration of order— He said it was in the highest degree unjust to make the fate of persons under prosecution before a Court of Law to depend upon the conduct of any other persons than themselves— I replied to the parts of Mr Everett’s Speech, which assailed the principles sustained in my Report; and Everett intimated that if I had insisted upon them, there would have been a Counterreport exhibiting the views of that part of the Committee who dissented from mine— Mr Sullivan moved that the Draught of a Report prepared by me should be laid on the Table— This gave rise to some discussion, and to various motions. Dr Lowell, judge Fay, and James T. Austin replied to Mr Everett’s argument against the Prosecution at Law. Austin especially referred to many cases of prosecutions by persons even in the relations of husband and wife against each other— Dr Lowell referred to the Law of the University which makes it the duty of the Faculty to prosecute for trespasses which they cannot detect or punish themselves—and judge Fay expatiated upon the odious character of the privilege of exemption claimed by the Students. Mr Savage made a few remarks, and my draught of a Report was called for by several members— I said I had it in my pocket— That if the Board thought proper to hear it, I would read it now, even in its present condition—reserving to myself the right of revising it hereafter— But it would take upwards of an hour to read it; and the debate was running on, till past one O’Clock— A motion then was made to discharge the Committee from all further consideration of the subject, and to refer the Report already made, my draught and all the papers to a new Committee of which I should be Chairman, to report at an adjourned Meeting of the Board, next Monday at ten O’Clock AM. this motion prevailed, and Richard Sullivan, James Savage, the Revd Convers Francis and John Cotton, were the members appointed on the Committee— James T. Austin and Samuel P. P. Fay, were successively appointed by
the Chairman, but were excused at their own request, being much occupied about the riotous destruction of the Ursuline Convent at Charlestown— Mr Alexander H. Everett then made the report of the Committee upon the degrees to be conferred at the Commencement, all of which were approved— A Letter was received from Dr William Spooner with his resignation, from age and infirmity, of his Seat at the Board. They adjourned about a Quarter before two— I asked the members of the new Committee to stay; except Mr Cotton, who was gone— I put all the papers into the hands of Mr Savage,—and then it was agreed that the rest of the Committee should without my presence meet and examine my Report; propose such amendments and alterations as they shall think proper, and then transmit the papers to me by Sunday noon: and that I should meet them on Monday Morning at nine O’Clock. I dined with Dr George Parkman, and at 4. afternoon the State called for me and I returned to Quincy by six— Dr Shattuck and his Son, with Mrs Parkman and her Sister were all the company at dinner We had various amusements at Cards, in the Evening.
22. IV:30. Friday— Saw Sirius.

Before breakfast this morning, Mr Child came from Boston with Mr Mackintosh, who is a claimant for a Pension for having served in the same Corps of Artificers, to which Solomon Thayer belonged— Mr Mackintosh’s claim has not been admitted at the Department of War, and he had a Letter from Mr Edwards of the Pension Office stating that there is no Evidence at the Department that there was a Corps of Artificers in the Army. Mr Child had two parcels of depositions and other papers to prove Mr Mackintosh’s Services, and among them was a Resolution of the Congress at Watertown, rejecting a petition from the Corps of Artificers for an increase of their pay, and referring to the rates of pay fixed by the Resolution establishing the Corps— I suggested to Mr Child the expediency of examining the Journals of that Congress, for the record establishing the Corps, where the terms of engagement thus subsequently referred to must be found. He said he would make the search, and then send on the papers to the Commissioner of Pensions, or keep them till I shall go on to Washington, next winter— I said that as to the existence of the Corps of Artificers, it had been admitted by the Secretary of War, upon explanations verbally given by me to him, in the case of Solomon Thayer, whose Pension had been consequently increased by his order— I invited them to breakfast with us; but Mr Child said Mrs Child would be waiting for him, as he had promised to return to Breakfast, and they declined— Charles went into Boston, and returned to dine— I worked at weeding three hours in the garden and Nursery where I have had a man at the same work all this week, and it is not yet finished— The Diary of yesterday occupied all the remainder of the morning, and a few lines upon La Fayette the afternoon. We had cards this Evening, which I left, on receiving by a special Messenger a Letter from Richard Sullivan, returning the papers referred yesterday by the Board of
Overseers to the new Committee; they had their Meeting this afternoon; and generally approve my Report— They wish however to report only two Resolutions; one censuring the Circular of the Senior Class, and the other approving the proceedings of the faculty—omitting entirely that which recommended that the proceedings on the prosecution at Law should be discontinued—and they propose to expunge from my report the passages which allude to that recommendation— In this I shall readily acquiesce, as in the course of the discussion yesterday it was mentioned that there had been a Meeting of the Senior Class the day before, thinly attended, which had adjourned to meet again to-morrow, to determine whether they would perform their parts on Commencement day or not— I stated that I considered those meetings themselves as unlawful, and as proving that the third Resolution reported by the former Committee could not safely be adopted.
23. IV. Saturday— Saw Sirius and Orion.

Visited my garden and Nursery, but the heat of the Sun slackened my work; I have had a man occupied a whole week in weeding them, and it is yet unfinished— The man is from New Hampshire, named Butler, and he asked me to engage him for the next Spring— He said he understood Gardening having worked two years in a Garden. He is now going to work some time for Alpheus Spear, and I told him I would give him an answer to his proposal of engagement before winter— My remnant of time shortens every day, and the slow growth even of the trees and plants which I do succeed in drawing from the seed daily admonishes me, that I cannot be allowed to witness but to a very small extent the results of my own experiments— The walnut tree neat the Summer House cellar in the Garden, the nut of which I planted 8. October 1804, proves what might have been done in that time— I this day began planting a row of hazel slips, from South to North, along the Eastern fence of my Nursery—intending once a week for the next two Months, to continue it; with a view to ascertain; if any of them will take; and perhaps at what Season best. Harriet Welsh paid us a visit this afternoon, with a Mr and two Misses Newland of Fishkill, New-York— I bathed and swam at the Creek with Charles about two O’Clock, but wasted in idleness of lassitude the afternoon— In the evening they had whist and I was star-gazing—a beautiful, cloudless night— I received by a special Messenger a Letter from President Quincy informing me that he wished to speak with me upon a point of importance, and would call to see me to-morrow, after church. I revised my Report to the Board of Overseers, making it conformable to the views of the new Committee, as communicated to me by Mr Richard Sullivan, and Charles is making a fair copy of it.
24. IV:30 Sunday

Heard Mr Lunt a young preacher at large, who has been settled at New-York, and parted from his Congregation there— He preached here four Sundays in the month of June and has now engaged for two Sundays more— His morning text was from Romans 2.14 “For when the Gentiles, which have not the Law, do by nature, the things contained in the Law, these, having not the law, are a law unto themselves.” The general doctrine expounded and illustrated by the discourse was, what to be
understood by the words doing by nature, the things contained in the Law; it was a regulated, virtuous nature; and not the indulgence of vicious Passions— The original doctrine was that of the Stoics, and I believe there is something of it in Bishop Butler— Mr Lunt’s delivery is cool, and not without animation— He reads well— His reasoning is sound; his morality pure— His deficiency like that of almost all the young men of his profession is of pathos— His afternoon Sermon, was from Titus 2.11. “For the grace of God, that bringeth salvation hath appeared to all men, 12. Teaching us, that denying ungodliness, and worldly lusts, we should live soberly, righteously, and godly, in this present world.”— The argument was that in this passage, the practice of virtue was represented as taught by the grace of God; and it was ingeniously sustained— I read the first Sermon of the 6th. Volume of Saurin— Upon the Affliction caused by the death of those whom we love— I expected much from this title, but was disappointed— The text is from 1. Thessalonians 4.13–18. and the preacher instead of confining himself to his proper subject which is contained in the 13th and 14th. verses, launches into the difficulties of the subsequent verses and never extricates himself from them— He perplexes a subject in itself deeply pathetic with controversial commentary upon the specific mode of resurrection described by the Apostle; and so unintelligible, that he says he has particular reasons for believing this to be the very passage to which Peter alludes, in the assertion that there are in the Epistles of Paul some things hard to be understood— Mr Lunt and Louisa C. Smith dined with us— President Quincy came in the afternoon after public worship, and read to me a long paper that he had prepared to deliver at the Board of Overseers of the University, containing references to former cases of prosecutions at Law, of Students, from the year 1749 down to the present time; with a narrative of the disorderly state of the University when he was appointed President, of the measures which he took for the restoration of order, and of the alteration in 1829 of the Law of the University respecting the prosecution of Students in the Courts of Law— It had been previously discretionary, with the Faculty— It is now made their positive duty, in cases of aggravated trespasses. There was also, a very earnest argument to shew the indispensable necessity of resorting to the tribunals, for the preservation of Peace, Property and Persons belonging to the University— Mr Quincy said he had prepared this paper in consequence of my saying that he would be called upon before the Board of Overseers to justify the prosecutions at Law. He had understood me to mean, that I should call upon him; and that I was adverse to the prosecutions— I told him I had not intended to call upon him, unless it should be to answer objections from other quarters— I had wished to apprize him of questions which I knew would be made, and particularly to urge him to come armed with all the precedents that he could collect, in answer to the charge of innovation— I was therefore gratified to find that he had prepared this paper, and hoped it would be read to the Board of Overseers, and preserved among their Records—that my own Report was altogether in the same Spirit, and that it was entirely approved by the present Committee, and would be presented to the board to morrow. I asked him what information he had of the proceedings of the Senior Class— He said they had had a second meeting yesterday; and had passed and rescinded two or three Resolutions; but had finally resolved that those who had parts for Commencement, should perform them; but that they should all refuse to receive their degrees. I said that this
might perhaps occasion some riotous disturbance to the performances, or on the Evening of commencement day; and I hoped that he and the faculty would be prepared for any such event as might occur— He said he would call a meeting of the faculty tomorrow morning, and consult with them, upon the proper course to be pursued. He said he had been constantly, and ably supported by Dr Ware in every measure adopted by the faculty hitherto—but that he had great difficulties with the younger members even of that body— That three of the Tutors had been opposed to almost every measure adopted, and that the most important of all, the delay to give out the Parts for commencement, till after the Senior Class were separated, had been carried only by a majority of one— He specially complained of the Tutor M’Kean, son of a half-crazy professor there, now deceased, and who had himself been confined as a lunatic within eighteen months before he was appointed a Tutor—though this fact had been but recently made known to him— There was a long and copious Thunder shower towards Evening, and I invited Mr Quincy to take a bed with us, but he declined, and said he must at all hazards return this Evening to Cambridge
25 IV. Monday— Boston— Overseers Meeting— Quincy.

I went into Boston, with Charles— Met the U.S. Senators Tyler, and Mangum, who told me they had come to enter upon the examination of the U.S. Branch Bank at Boston, as members of the Bank investigation Committee of the Senate. I called at the Savings Bank Office, for Mr Savage, who went with me to the Council Chamber at 9 O’Clock—the other members of the Committee, Richard Sullivan Cotton, and Revd. Convers Francis were already there— The Committee agreed unanimously to my draught of Report, with several amendments, to which I assented. They agreed also to propose a Resolution, as a substitute for that which recommended the withdrawal of the Prosecution, which it was now proposed to strike out— The new Resolution I proposed to stand as the first, and declared that the Students of Harvard University have no just or equitable claim to exemption from prosecution in the Courts of Law, for trespasses upon property or against Persons, whether belonging to the University or otherwise— To this Resolution, after some objection from Mr Francis, supported by Mr Sullivan the Committee, at last unanimously agreed— At ten O’Clock the board of Overseers met. 21 members present, and I read my report, which took an hour and a quarter— After it was read, and the three Resolutions with which it concluded, the Lieutt. Governor as Chairman enquired what disposal should be made of the Report, Coll. Pickman, after a pause of two or three minutes moved that it be accepted— Mr John Welles made a short Speech; commending the Report, approving the motion that it should be accepted, and moved further that it be entered at large, on the Records of the Board, printed and extensively circulated— This gave rise to a debate which continued about two hours— Sidney Willard moved to strike out from the Report, every allusion to the withdrawal of the prosecutions; but was not seconded, and did not persist in the motion— The debate became quite desultory; judge John Davis approved the Sentiments of the Report, though he said it was a melancholy one; but thought it an unfortunate time for its publication— He saw an inconsistency, in adopting so severe a censure upon the conduct of the young men, at the very time when the honours of the University were to be conferred upon them— He suggested the expediency of holding no Commencement the present year— He spoke of the recent Meetings held by the members of the Senior Class, and enquired if President Quincy had any information of their proceedings. Mr Quincy said his information was not very precise. There
were fourteen members of the Class, who had taken no part in any of the disturbances; six who had not attended the recent Meetings; these twenty were ready to perform their parts and take their degrees— There were twenty-eight who had held two Meetings last week, and passed and rescinded several Resolutions— Their last Resolution was that those who had parts should perform them; but that all should refuse to accept their degrees— This they had done, in the expectation that they should receive their degrees the next year with the eight members of the Class who have already been declared to have forfeited their degrees for the present year— The faculty had therefore had a Meeting this Morning, and resolved, that the President should send for every individual members of the Class, and demand of him, whether he would perform his part, and receive his degree—and in case of his failing to answer satisfactorily on both points, the President should inform him that he will have neither part nor degree, and that the faculty will never recommend him hereafter, for the reception of a degree— There now ensued various propositions, and at last a vote to take a question upon each of the three Resolutions appended to the Report, separately, and they were all unanimously adopted— Then came the question upon the acceptance of the Report— James T. Austin proposed that the President should send for the whole Class and read to them the Report and the Resolutions, and give them an opportunity to reply to them. He spoke of the Report in extravagant and invidious terms of commendation— Thought some of its expressions ought to have been softened, and said it was the severest punishment that had ever been inflicted upon any Student of Harvard— He repeated indeed the remarks made by Governor Lincoln, at the first meeting of the former Committee, in language so identical, that I concluded Lincoln had told him what passed at that Meeting— Chief Justice Shaw answered Mr Austin very fully— He said the Report was no punishment, nor was it to be understood as such— The punishments had been inflicted by the Government of the University— The Report was a review of all the transactions both of the immediate Government and of the Students—made by a Committee of the Overseers to them— It spoke of the past conduct of these young men with severity—this was not part of their punishment, nor so intended—it was incidental to the exposition of the condition of the University, which the Committee was charged to present, but formed no part of the punishment— I observed that it was analogous to the remarks which it is usual for judges to make, on pronouncing sentence upon a criminal. Those remarks might occasionally be felt by the criminal, as a punishment more severe than the sentence itself, but formed no part of the punishment— I added that the Resolutions as adopted were th act of the Overseers, and expressive of their Sense— That the Report was merely the act of their Committee addressed to them, and at their disposal— And I hoped if the board should direct that it should be printed, they would not permit its publication; for I believed its first effect would be to irritate and inflame the temper of the young men, censured in it; make them pass an unpleasant Commencement day which was far from my wish or intention, and perhaps even excite them further to fresh disorders, injurious to themselves— Dr Lowell concurred, in these views; he wished the acceptance of the report now, and its publication hereafter. His hope
was that its tendency would be to prevent the recurrence of such disorders hereafter, and having himself a Son to enter the present year, it would be with terror, rather than with satisfaction, if he could not indulge this hope. Mr Quincy said it would be impossible for him to call the Class together and read this paper before commencement morning; the Students themselves being occupied with their own preparations for Commencement; and the inauguration of three Professors which was fixed for tomorrow necessarily absorbing his time— Mr Austin’s motion was not supported, and the Report was accepted with only one dissenting voice, which was that of judge Davis— He said his objection was only to the time and not to the Sentiments in the Report— Mr Savage moved that President Quincy should cause the publication to be made after Commencement; but Dr Lowell made some objection to this, and I said I should be content to leave it at the discretion of the President, upon which Mr Savage withdrew his motion, and the meeting was dissolved. I asked President Quincy that when my Report should be printed, the vote for which was unanimous, he would have a proof sheet of it sent to me for revisal—he promised that he would— He shewed me a Letter from one of the refractory Seniors named La Branche, one of the first in the Class; full of compunction and bitter regret— Acknowledging and thanking Mr Quincy for the kindness which he had uniformly shewn him; and lamenting the necessity under which he felt himself of declining to take his degree but declaring that he could not conform to the vote of the Class, to perform their parts and then refuse the degree, and that he should therefore not perform his part. A curious Letter, and strong exemplification of the convulsive struggle in the mind, between the sense of right, the consciousness of wrong, and the cowardly Spirit of dishonest combination— Immediately after the Meeting of the Overseers adjourned, I went to my Son Charles’s Office, and we returned to Quincy to dine— President Quincy had expressed himself, extremely well satisfied, and grateful for the support given to him and to the Government of the College in my report— After dinner I visited my garden and nursery; Evening visit from Mr Peter Whitney; and walked with him to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, where our Ladies had been to tea—and where we found assembled a company of twenty persons— We came home about 9 O’Clock.
26. V. Tuesday.

My wife and my Son Charles went to Boston this morning, and returned home to dine. I devoted the morning to the Journal of the last two days, and did not finish that of yesterday— After dinner I spent two hours in my garden and Nursery, unable from the heat of the Sun to dig, which is my hardest labour, and not so well prepared, as when fresh in the morning for observation— The second vegetation of the Oaks is ceasing— The Horse Chesnut and the Button wood are falling into the sear and yellow leaf— The decays of Autumn are coming on, and observation itself has no longer the same charm, as when it is exercised upon the production and growth of Plants. I propose for the future not to indulge myself with the idle pleasures of my garden till after dinner, when I find it more irksome to write, and even to read— The temptation to the waste of time in the morning is too great— I was
however interrupted this afternoon, by visits from Messrs. Webster, Mangum, Tyler and Ewing, the Bank investigation Committee of the U.S. Senate—and Mrs T. B. Adams with her family spent the Evening here— Mr Webster gave me an invitation to dine with him next Thursday, which I accepted, and I received from President Quincy a notice of the Boylston prize declamations on Thursday morning, with an invitation to dine with him that day— I wrote him a few lines, enclosing copies of the Votes at the Board of Overseers and appointment of the Committees on the 31st. ulto. and 21st. instt. to be printed with my report, and the other papers, relating to the disturbances at the University— I should have noted that at the meeting of the Overseers on the 21st. a Letter was received from Dr William Spooner, resigning, for age and infirmity his Seat as a member of the Board, and that at the Meeting yesterday neither Alexander H. nor Edward Everett was present.
27. IV:15. Wednesday. Commencement at Harvard University

Charles and Walter Hellen went to Cambridge, and attended the Commencement, which passed off without disorder; and a larger number of the Class took their degrees than had been anticipated— There was a meeting of the graduates of the University, upon a project to raise a sum of one hundred thousand dollars, in aid of the funds of the Institution— I passed the day quietly at home—the morning in my Library, and afternoon chiefly in my Garden and Nursery— Mary Louisa was unwell with symptoms of a bilious fever, and Dr Woodward was sent for to attend her— Alpheus Spear was here this morning—I had not been able to go to the Mount Wollaston farm as I had proposed last Wednesday— Spear was anxious about the renewal of his Lease which he thought would expire, next April; but I shewed him my copy of the Lease by which it runs till April 1836. and he said he wished to let it lie over till next Summer for consideration about renewal.
