I brought up my arrears; and the index to the end of 1833. but wrote only a few lines upon La Fayette— I was not satisfied with my afternoon’s work in the Garden, where it is my wish to do something every day— It was near nine this Evening when Charles and Walter got home.
28. IV.30. Thursday— Cambridge— Boston— Quincy.

I went to Cambridge with Wilson in Carr’s Chaise with Wilson and one of the Carriage horses— I attended a few minutes after nine in President Quincy’s Study— The judges of the Boylston prize Declamations present were twelve—we proceeded to the new Meeting House, the old one being now demolished—and took Seats in the two central pews— The competitors for the prizes were eight— Six of the present Senior Class, and two graduates of the present year— No Juniors; the whole of that Class with the exception of three having been dismissed. There was much equality among the performers; and no one of them very good— On returning to the President’s Study—one of the two first prizes was at the second ballot awarded to George Cabot. At the first ballot he had six votes without any previous comparison
of opinions between the judges— Dennis had four and there were two blanks. At the second ballot Cabot had seven votes— I then made it a question, whether the second first prize should be conferred, which gave rise to a short debate— Mr Walker of Charlestown said he had put in a blank at the first ballot, because he thought neither of the first prizes ought to be conferred— The speaking was all good; but none of it excellent— Judge Story was very ardently of a different opinion— It was found after some discussion that the vote was six and six, upon which came a question whether this was a decision to give or to refuse the prize— Judge Story and Mr Walker now changed sides—the judge thinking the majority necessary to grant, and Mr Walker to deny— Mr F. C. Gray read the rule of the founder which was that the judges might if they thought proper withhold the prizes— And the affirmative being to withhold, the tie did not make a vote, and the second first prize was awarded to Dennis. Both these were Seniors— At the first ballot for the first second prize there was no majority for any one— It was then voted to ballot for the three at once—and there were eleven for Wellington, one of the two graduates; 11 for Blake, and 9 for West, both Seniors— I had proposed that in awarding the prizes there should be some consideration of the taste and judgment exercised in the selection of the pieces for declamation—this was vehemently opposed by judge Story, and raised another debate— I mentioned as an instance, one of the pieces delivered this day; not well selected; and although as well spoken as any of the others, I had not voted to award a prize to the Speaker; and he had not in fact a single vote— I urged also that one of the prizes should be awarded to one of the graduates, on account of the circumstances in which the Class was situated towards the Government of the University and before the public— One of the second prizes was accordingly awarded to Wellington. Mr Quincy observed that neither of the two graduate competitors had taken any part in the late disturbances— It was half past twelve when the judges returned to the Meeting House, and then took Seats on the Stage— The auditory was assembled for the ΦB.K. performances, and the house was crowded— The Oration was delivered by William Howard Gardiner, a lawyer in Boston, son of the late Dr John Silvester John Gardiner and was an admirable defence and vindication of the Study of classical learning— It was two full hours in the delivery, and not much too long— It was admirably well spoken, and rivetted the attention of the auditory almost to the last moment. Never was the cause of classical Literature pleaded with more eloquence and beauty— The Poem by Ralph Waldo-Emerson was a slovenly performance, the only merit of which was its brevity. It was five minutes past 3 when the performances closed, and I went immediately into Boston, walked round the Borders of the common, reflecting on the various turns of fate below, and especially on all the vicissitudes which have befallen me, since on the 5th. of August 1809 I left the House at the Corner of Boylston Street where Charles was born, and embarked for St. Petersburg—what an age of hope, and disappointment—of good and evil fortune I have since gone through— Prosperous on the whole beyond the ordinary chances of human life—but with how many deep afflictions, with how many cruel humiliations! I went to Mr Daniel Webster’s and dined— Mrs Webster, his Son and daughter
Mr Stephen White, Mr and Mrs Page, and their child, a little girl two years and a half old—N. Silsbee, Stephen C Phillips, Alexander H and Edward Everett, Mr Walcott from Middlesex County, and the Senators, Tyler, Mangum, and Ewing, constituted the Company. The dinner was excellent—the wines various, the conversation cold, cautious, and under constant restraint— About half past seven, I left the Gentlemen at table, the Ladies having retired, and got home before nine— Found Mr Beale, with his daughter Ann, and Mr and Mrs Emmons on a visit to our Ladies— A weary day.
29. IV:30 Friday.

Charles and Walter Hellen, went to Boston and thence in the Steam-boat, to Nahant, and returned this Evening. Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us, and spent the day with the Ladies— I spent the morning till dinnertime in my Library, but without progress except in my daily records. Mr Grimké, is the second Son of Thomas S. Grimké, an eminent Lawyer and Citizen of Charleston South-Carolina, from whom he brought a Letter, recommending him and a companion named Ralph Izard Middleton, but he did not come with him— His companion was a young Mr Dehon, brother of Mrs Sidney Brooks. Mr Grimké said he expected his father would arrive this day or to-morrow at Bristol, Rhode-Island, and should then go on Monday to meet him— I went immediately after dinner into my Garden; but was called back to two other visitors from Charleston South-Carolina—Mr Yeadon, Editor of the Charleston Courier, who brought me a Letter from Joel R. Poinsett, and Mr Levi, whom he introduced to me, as a Citizen of Charleston— Mr Yeadon spoke with some concern of the political condition of South-Carolina, where the nullification and Union parties are still at issue with each other, and still mutually inveterate— I observed that in that controversy, the union party had conceded too much to their adversaries.— Levi said that if so, Mr Jefferson’s doctrine was the cause of it; and that if the Union party had not held out a strong adhesion to State rights, they would have been officers without an army— Mr Yeadon said they had much anxiety about the appointment of a judge of the Supreme Court, in the place of Judge Johnson, and hoped it would be Mr Pettigrew—Coll Drayton having by his removal to Philadelphia, ceased to be considered a citizen of South-Carolina. He said further that when President Jackson’s first Cabinet was broken up, he offered the Office of Secretary of War to Coll. Drayton, by whom it was declined—and that Drayton was the real head and founder of the Union party— He said too that at the next Session of the Legislature, the nullification party would call a convention of the People, and thereby procure an Amendment to the Constitution of the State, prescribing the test Oath to establish the State authorities as the only Sovereign powers in this Union— And he alluded to the apprehension always prevailing in the South, that the People of the North have a perpetual propensity to promote the abolition of Slavery in the South— This Ghost I believe will haunt them, till they bring it up in reality— I said I had no longer the confidence in the long duration of the Union that I once had—but did not say why—
30. V. Saturday.

My Son Charles, his wife and two children, with their Nursery maid, Catherine left us this morning and returned to Medford, where Charles’s wife is keeping her father Mr Brooks’s House for the Summer— I had morning visits from Minott Thayer, and Mr Miller, whom he introduced as Sheriff of New Brunswick His father was originally from this neighbourhood, and Thayer said, once lived in this house—in 1780— Miller’s visit was short, but long enough to discover the refugee Soul. Thayer was speaking of the frequency of our elections, and asked Miller how often they had them in New-Brunswick— He said once in seven years, and he wished they were only once in twenty years— I asked him the cause of his aversion to elections— He said they were always violently contested—and caused heats and dissensions— Tory doctrines treble distilled, must be the natural productions of New-Brunswick and Nova-Scotia. President Quincy was also here, with the proof sheets of my Report to the Overseers, on the recent disturbances at the University— He said the faculty had determined to have 1500 copies of the papers printed; and asked how many copies I should wish to have— I said twenty would be as many as I should want— I revised the proof, which as usual much needed it, and he took the papers back with him— He is in very high Spirits at the issue thus far of his troubles, and I hope understands that he is not yet out of them— He said there had been admitted 76 students into the Freshman Class; and that a large portion of the late Sophomore Class had applied for readmission; and were to pass examination this day— I indulge hopes that the sequel of this controversy may promote the cause of good morals, and the interests of the University— But with these hopes are mingled painful apprehensions both with regard to my friend; to the laxity of discipline, so irresistibly spreading, and to the prospects of the coming age— After dinner I visited my Garden and Nursery, where the education of my seedling plants, presents in miniature, almost as many difficulties, and problems to solve, as the education of children at School and College. Spent the Evening in my Library; busied with small occupations.
31. IV:15. Sunday.

Heard Mr Lunt in the morning from 2. Timothy 1.7. “For God hath not given us the Spirit of fear; but of power, of love, and of a sound mind.”— And in the afternoon from Galatians 5.6 “For in Jesus Christ neither Circumcision availeth any thing, nor uncircumcision: but Faith which worketh by Love.” The two discourses appeared to be parts of one Sermon; the subject of which was the Spirit of Christianity— The illustrations of the morning were chiefly confined to the negative portion of the text, shewing that the predominating principle of the gospel was not Fear—and those of the afternoon, were to mark the discrimination, between that Faith which worketh by Love, and other modes of Faith. There was little or no direct allusion to the Calvinistic doctrines of election, reprobation, and atonement, but the bearing of the whole argument was—These doctrines are all founded in the Spirit of Fear—and the Faith, which they exact is not that which worketh by Love
The texts were both well selected, and the deductions from them very ingeniously drawn— The scope of both the discourses was closely argumentative; to prove that the vital spirit of Christianity is not Fear, but Love— There was a notice of a Town-Meeting at 4 tomorrow afternoon, to consider an application for a road, to pass through my Penn’s hill Land. . . . read the second Sermon of the 6th. Volume of Saurin—upon the famine of the word of God— It is principally a lamentation upon the condition of the French Protestants under the proscriptive Edict of Louis the 14th. revoking the Edict of Nantes—a melancholy historical contemplation— I wrote an Epitaph to be inscribed on the Monument of General Brown; and a short letter to Ephraim Kirby, his Son in Law, enclosing it for the inspection and revisal of General Brown’s widow and family. This is a task which has hung several weeks upon my hands, and which ought to have been performed before— Lieutt. T. B. Adams and Elizabeth were here this Evening; and my Grand-child Mary-Louisa who has been several days unwell, was so ill that Dr Woodward was sent for after nine at Night— He says she has the Cholera Morbus.

Day— Generally the same as last Month— I am now reading in Thomson’s Bible the Book of Ezechiel, and this as well as its predecessors Esaias and Jeremias, is to me more unintelligible and far less sublime than in King James’s English Bible— The Chapters are transposed almost throughout the whole Book of Jeremias, and in many parts of Ezechiel— There is no unity of composition, and very little of sequel in the three larger prophets—not much in the smaller. I found that my garden and nursery were engrossing so many of my morning hours; and that it was so irksome to me to write after dinner, that I was wasting inexcusably my time— I changed therefore the time of my garden visits to the afternoon, and give the whole morning to my closet— This experiment I have persevered in, nearly a week, but it has as yet produced no fruits. The month has been much occupied with the disturbances at the University— Three Meetings of the Board of Overseers, and three of Committees appointed by them, with the preparation and discussion of a long Report, have greatly diverted my attention from La Fayette, which I hope may now return to him— My Correspondence still runs in arrear.
